evidence_span: he drew a limit line on the plot of the rod surface heat flux versus days to failure after cladding breach...limiting levels of operation are about 120 to $1 5 0 { \cdot } \mathbf { W } / \mathbf { c m } ^ { \colon }$ peak flux at a coolant temperature of 533 to $6 3 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk8
evidence_span: Out-of-pile zirconium hydriding test data in H₂/H₂O gas mixtures shows that specimen characteristics (geometry and surface conditions) as well as environmental factors (hydrogen pressure, test temperature, and test time) affect the amount of hydrogen pickup in Zircaloy. In addition, the type of Zircaloy (2 or 4), the heat treatment, and minor variations in the alloying conditions were also found to influence hydrogen absorption.
conditions: H₂/H₂O gas mixtures, various hydrogen pressures, test temperatures, and test times

extra_properties.hydrogen_pickup: affected by specimen characteristics and environmental factors

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk9
evidence_span: Out-of-reactor corrosion tests in 10.3-MPa steam at temperatures between 490 and 530°C have been carried out on Zircaloy-2 tube specimens

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk10
evidence_span: Nodular corrosion on Zircaloy fuel cladding has been observed as early as the end of the first cycle in boiling water reactors (BWRs)
